Threatening, abusive, intolerant or illegal behaviour will lead to moderation and/or account deletion.
Do not post anything that is illegal in Queensland, Australia - this service and all data stored on it is 100% stored and operated in QLD.
Do not knowingly share false or misleading information.
The Content Warning flag must be used for NSFW content, and NSFW media should be marked as sensitive.
Registrations are monitored and accounts considered spam, duplicates, impersonating legal entities or persons will be deleted.
Always be kind to each other. Don't say anything you wouldn't face to face.

records.text: I dunno if I'll ever stop pursuing IT certifications. To me, they're such a good way to build a skill from nothing. I don't expect anyone to be particularly interested in this, it's just some thoughts I needed to get out of my head. In 2017, I knew nothing about networking, I didn't even have a particularly strong grasp on what a subnet mask was for. I had a little meltdown while I was trying to escape my deadend job in insurance and started on a journey to certifying with my CCNA. In 2018, I achieved the first half of it and still struggled to find work (featuring sexism and a conservative job market/city) until later that year when I got my break onto a service desk.I completed my CCNA in 2019 and used those skills extensively in my first non-helpdesk job, though they didn't want to admit they were using my skills, so wouldn't pay me more or even reimburse my certification.In 2022, I passed my RHCSA and it filled in a lot of little gaps that I'd had from having self-taught myself Linux as a teenager (and trial by fire in a job). I did this again under my own financing because I needed the tax deduction that year.Then last year to renew my CCNA, I studied and sat for the Cisco Certified DevNet Associate - part of it was to get the renewal and part of it was because I was interested in breaking into the DevOps space. It taught me heaps about the basic concepts and I used those in home projects. A few months later, I got a job in that space and have been working towards my CKA - this time, paid for by my employer. It's interesting how many little things each of these certs has taught me that I hadn't picked up in my own self-study and how much those foundational skills have helped me build more intermediate ones. To me, the certificate is like the shiny little medal I get at the end and whilst I strictly don't need it, my lizard brain wants it.

records.text: I dunno if I'll ever stop pursuing IT certifications. To me, they're such a good way to build a skill from nothing. I don't expect anyone to be particularly interested in this, it's just some thoughts I needed to get out of my head. In 2017, I knew nothing about networking, I didn't even have a particularly strong grasp on what a subnet mask was for. I had a little meltdown while I was trying to escape my deadend job in insurance and started on a journey to certifying with my CCNA. In 2018, I achieved the first half of it and still struggled to find work (featuring sexism and a conservative job market/city) until later that year when I got my break onto a service desk.I completed my CCNA in 2019 and used those skills extensively in my first non-helpdesk job, though they didn't want to admit they were using my skills, so wouldn't pay me more or even reimburse my certification.In 2022, I passed my RHCSA and it filled in a lot of little gaps that I'd had from having self-taught myself Linux as a teenager (and trial by fire in a job). I did this again under my own financing because I needed the tax deduction that year.Then last year to renew my CCNA, I studied and sat for the Cisco Certified DevNet Associate - part of it was to get the renewal and part of it was because I was interested in breaking into the DevOps space. It taught me heaps about the basic concepts and I used those in home projects. A few months later, I got a job in that space and have been working towards my CKA - this time, paid for by my employer. It's interesting how many little things each of these certs has taught me that I hadn't picked up in my own self-study and how much those foundational skills have helped me build more intermediate ones. To me, the certificate is like the shiny little medal I get at the end and whilst I strictly don't need it, my lizard brain wants it.

records.text: I dunno if I'll ever stop pursuing IT certifications. To me, they're such a good way to build a skill from nothing. I don't expect anyone to be particularly interested in this, it's just some thoughts I needed to get out of my head. In 2017, I knew nothing about networking, I didn't even have a particularly strong grasp on what a subnet mask was for. I had a little meltdown while I was trying to escape my deadend job in insurance and started on a journey to certifying with my CCNA. In 2018, I achieved the first half of it and still struggled to find work (featuring sexism and a conservative job market/city) until later that year when I got my break onto a service desk.I completed my CCNA in 2019 and used those skills extensively in my first non-helpdesk job, though they didn't want to admit they were using my skills, so wouldn't pay me more or even reimburse my certification.In 2022, I passed my RHCSA and it filled in a lot of little gaps that I'd had from having self-taught myself Linux as a teenager (and trial by fire in a job). I did this again under my own financing because I needed the tax deduction that year.Then last year to renew my CCNA, I studied and sat for the Cisco Certified DevNet Associate - part of it was to get the renewal and part of it was because I was interested in breaking into the DevOps space. It taught me heaps about the basic concepts and I used those in home projects. A few months later, I got a job in that space and have been working towards my CKA - this time, paid for by my employer. It's interesting how many little things each of these certs has taught me that I hadn't picked up in my own self-study and how much those foundational skills have helped me build more intermediate ones. To me, the certificate is like the shiny little medal I get at the end and whilst I strictly don't need it, my lizard brain wants it.

records.text: I dunno if I'll ever stop pursuing IT certifications. To me, they're such a good way to build a skill from nothing. I don't expect anyone to be particularly interested in this, it's just some thoughts I needed to get out of my head. In 2017, I knew nothing about networking, I didn't even have a particularly strong grasp on what a subnet mask was for. I had a little meltdown while I was trying to escape my deadend job in insurance and started on a journey to certifying with my CCNA. In 2018, I achieved the first half of it and still struggled to find work (featuring sexism and a conservative job market/city) until later that year when I got my break onto a service desk.I completed my CCNA in 2019 and used those skills extensively in my first non-helpdesk job, though they didn't want to admit they were using my skills, so wouldn't pay me more or even reimburse my certification.In 2022, I passed my RHCSA and it filled in a lot of little gaps that I'd had from having self-taught myself Linux as a teenager (and trial by fire in a job). I did this again under my own financing because I needed the tax deduction that year.Then last year to renew my CCNA, I studied and sat for the Cisco Certified DevNet Associate - part of it was to get the renewal and part of it was because I was interested in breaking into the DevOps space. It taught me heaps about the basic concepts and I used those in home projects. A few months later, I got a job in that space and have been working towards my CKA - this time, paid for by my employer. It's interesting how many little things each of these certs has taught me that I hadn't picked up in my own self-study and how much those foundational skills have helped me build more intermediate ones. To me, the certificate is like the shiny little medal I get at the end and whilst I strictly don't need it, my lizard brain wants it.
